Isobutane/butene alkylation reaction using ionic liquids as catalysts. Toward a sustainable industry Diego Guzmán-Lucero Javier Guzmán-Pantoja Heriberto Díaz Velázquez Natalya V. Likhanova Mercedes Bazaldua-Domínguez Araceli Vega-Paz Rafael Martínez-Palou ⁎ Dirección de Investigación en Transformación de Hidrocarburos. Instituto Mexicano del Petróleo. Eje Central L. The isobutane/butene alkylation reaction is one of the most crucial refining processes since it gives rise to high octane and high purity gasoline, one of the main contributors to the gasoline pool. Conventionally, the alkylation reaction is carried out industrially using hydrofluoric and sulfuric acids, which have significant safety, corrosivity, recyclability, and sustainability concerns, making the development of efficient, environmentally friendly, and sustainable catalysts for this reaction an active research topic. Due to their attractive physicochemical properties, ionic liquids seem to be the most promising alternative to replace the catalysts commonly used at the industrial level. The present compendium reviews research works to develop ionic liquids as catalysts of the isobutane/butane reaction to obtain a more efficient, sustainable, and environmentally friendly process. These compounds can mitigate the environmental problems associated with inorganic acids that have been used for many years as catalysts of this reaction on an industrial scale. The most recent articles and patents dealing with the advances in the alkylation reaction employing commercial technologies to obtain alkylated gasoline based on ionic-liquid catalysts, which have not been featured in previous reviews, are emphasized and discussed here. million RON Research octane number TPY Tons per year XDR X-ray diffraction NMR Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Introduction The alkylation of isobutane through the reaction with C3-C5 olefinic streams mainly results in isooctane, known as alkylated gasoline. The high demand of this compound as part of the gasoline pool is justified, for it provides desirable properties, such as high octane values (93–97), low Reid vapor pressure, low concentration of sulfur, nitrogen, olefinic and aromatic compounds, as well as clean combustion components [1]. However, current technologies, which date back to the 1940s, use either sulfuric (H2SO4) or hydrofluoric acid (HF) for its production. To date, a very high percentage of alkylate gasoline produced worldwide uses these inorganic catalysts. The main disadvantage of current production methods is related to the conditions for the industrial handling of these acids and the accidents that have been recorded due to HF leaks and their capacity to form aerosols with lethal HF concentrations [2]. H2SO4 is currently used as a catalyst in industrial plants since it is stable and has good catalytic performance; unfortunately, alkylation requires high acid consumption, which raises the production cost, and its regeneration can only be done 2 or 3 times [3]. Countless research efforts have been carried out in the search for other more environmentally friendly and low toxicity catalysts, which is the case of zeolite-based catalysts that can be very efficient and selective, but so far, the rapid deactivation problems shown by these catalysts have not been overcome yet, mainly due to the formation of coke that blocks the active sites of these materials [4,5]. So far, the most promising alternative for replacing conventional toxic catalysts is the use of ionic liquids (ILs). Compared to other conventional catalysts, a significant advantage of ILs is that their acidity can be adjusted with great precision. Thus, it becomes one of the most valuable variables in maximizing alkylate quality. ILs derived from organometallic compounds represents one promising alternative to conventional acids due to their adaptation suitability to Lewis and Brønsted acidity [6]. It is known that HCl dissolved in an organochloroaluminate-IL is a Brønsted superacid, comparable to 100% H2SO4 [7,8]. The disadvantage of IL-catalysts derived from chloroaluminates is that they are irreversibly deactivated due to their high sensitivity to moisture, leading to their decomposition and HCl release. For this reason, although commercial prototypes of these catalysts applied at the industrial level already exist, research works focused on the development of IL-based catalysts to perform the alkylation reaction are still looking for prototypes that are both more chemically stable and environmentally friendly [9]. This paper summarizes the most recent developments featuring ILs as catalysts for the alkylation reaction between isobutane/butenes from the academic and industrial process points of view, emphasizing the most recent articles and patents that have not been discussed in previous reviews of this subject matter. Ionic liquids (ILs) ILs are salts that, at room temperature, are in the liquid state and are composed solely of ions. Many of them consist of a large organic cation and a small anion, which can be either organic or inorganic [10]. ILs’ physical and chemical properties (polarity, hydrophobicity, and miscibility, among others) can be modulated, depending on the cation and anion that make them up, with numerous possible combinations. Imidazolium, pyridinium, ammonium, pyrrolidinium, and phosphonium are among the most common cations, while the most common anions are halides (first generation IL), such as [(trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl]imide (NTf2 −), hexafluorophosphate, (PF6 −), tetrafluoroborates (BF4 −), trifluoroacetate (CF3COO−), trifluoromethylsulfonate (CF3SO3 −) and acetate (CH3COO−), among others (Fig. 1 ) [11]. Ionic liquids’ properties Among the properties of ILs that make them particularly attractive are: • Ability to engineer specific physical and chemical properties. The most valuable property of ILs is their ability to "engineer" or "modulate" their physical and chemical properties by modifying the cation side chains and properly selecting the anion. Thus, ILs can be designed based on their desired physical and chemical characteristics [12]. • Low pressure (or no vapor pressure). Since ILs are salts in the liquid state, they have little or no vapor pressure. Due to this property, ILs do not evaporate even at high temperatures (below 300 °C), which allows them to be fully recovered and recycled. This property makes them attractive as substitutes for today's volatile organic solvents [13]. • Low melting point. This property allows them to be liquid at room temperature, which can be attributed to the asymmetry of the ions constituting the ILs as it prevents their compact packing. The melting point mainly depends on the size of the ions involved in the ILs and their charge and distribution. The larger the size of the cation and anion, the lower the melting point. Similarly, an increase in the ions' asymmetry decreases the IL's melting point [14]. • High polarity. The high polarity (ability to stabilize a charge) is one of the most innate properties of ILs. The polarity displayed by ILs is similar to that observed in polar molecular solvents such as ethanol and formamide. The polar character of ILs makes them an ideal medium for chemical and biochemical reactions due to their ability to dissolve different substances, including organic, inorganic, polar, non-polar, and polymeric compounds [15]. • Miscibility in water. ILs may or may not be miscible in water. The ILs miscibility depends mainly on the anion's hydrophobicity due to the hydrogen bonding interaction with water, although, sometimes, the cation also plays a notorious role in miscibility [16]. However, extending the alkyl chain length of the cation can decrease the miscibility due to its increased hydrophobicity. In addition, the water miscibility of ILs can be modulated depending on the type of anion and cation. • Miscibility in organic compounds. ILs are generally immiscible in many organic solvents, especially if the latter are non-polar such as hexane, while others may be miscible in polar solvents such as dichloromethane and tetrahydrofuran. The immiscibility of ILs in either water or organic solvents makes them ideal for forming two-phase systems [17]. • Recoverability and reusability. Since the miscibility of ILs depends on their structure, the reaction products can be recovered by extraction using water, supercritical CO2, or organic solvents. • Thermal stability. ILs are stable at high temperatures; in some cases, they have a thermal decomposition temperature greater than 250 °C. This property makes ILs useful in reactions that require high or low temperatures. • Catalytic properties. ILs have been described as excellent catalysts for many organic reactions [18–21]. • High dissolution power. Many components are sufficiently soluble in ILs to perform reactions; due to this property, ILs have found application in removing contaminants from the oil industry [22]. ILs are currently used in several industrial processes, and they play an essential role in the chemical industry because they have enabled cleaner and more environmentally friendly technologies [23]. Alkylation mechanism The alkylation reaction in an acidic liquid medium consists of 3 main steps: [1,24,25] • Initiation: formation of a tertiary carbene ion, generated by the protonation of 2-butene. • Alkylation: addition of the tertiary carbene ion to a 2-butene molecule, the reaction occurs via electrophilic addition, where the butene π-bonds are broken, forming a new σ-bond at the alkyl cation, it is an exothermic reaction, and then it can generate other reaction possibilities. • Isomerization and Hydride Transfer: It involves the termination step that generates the C8 products, mainly trimethylpentane (TMP) isomers, and a new carbocation from isobutane (Fig. 2 ). In the alkylation step, secondary reactions such as isomerization and polymerization (competitive reactions producing C9+ heavy alkanes) occur [26]. From the tert-butyl ion, the carbenium ion trimethylpentane (TMP+) is generated, and from the sec-butyl ion, the carbenium ion dimethylhexane (DMH+) can be generated; between the two ions, a competition occurs [27]. The formation of different C8 isomers has also been explained by adding a t-butyl carbocation with different olefin isomers (Fig. 3 ). Researchers have studied this reaction by proposing different pathways using deuterated isobutane, such as self-alkylation of isobutane. Liu et al. [28] studied the alkylation of deuterated isobutane with 2-butene using both a Lewis and an IL as catalysts in continuous flow equipment to gather evidence to elucidate the mechanism of this reaction. It was observed that due to the high solubility of isobutane in an acidic medium, the induction period of alkylation in IL is shorter than in H2SO4. By analyzing the deuterated product distributions, the TMP fractions mainly come from the isobutane autoalkylation, from the direct alkylation reaction of C4 hydrocarbons, and the cleavage C12+ intermediates. The alkylation reaction using isobutane/2-butene and sulfuric acid is fast, and because isobutane has low solubility in H2SO4, the mass transfer from isobutane to sulfuric acid is presumably the controlling step of this process [29]. Increasing the solubility between isobutane and butene by adding surfactant additives to H2SO4 makes possible to increase the selectivity to TMP formation [27]. Furthermore, it has been shown that by modulating the acidity of the catalyst, it is possible to favor the selectivity to C8 formation [30]. Therefore, the Hammett acidity function, H0, which measures Brønsted acidity in organic media (logarithmic, exponential scale base 10) should be less than −8.2, and the optimum acid pKa of −10.7 [31]. Organic acids have the characteristic of solubilizing isolefins, such as trifluoroacetic acid (CF3COOH, TFA), which is a weak acid and less viscous than H2SO4. In this context, Li and co-workers evaluated the effects of H2SO4:TFA on the alkylation process of isobutane/2-butene by modifying the TFA concentration, in addition to studying some variables such as stirring speed, temperature, reaction time, isobutane/2-butene ratio, acid/hydrocarbon ratio and catalyst recycling [32]. These authors found that the highest stirring speed improved the selectivity to C8 (the optimal was 1000 rpm) to 76%. The reaction was performed from 4 to 20 °C, finding that the suitable temperature was 4 °C to achieve selectivity to C8 of 95%. Low temperatures favored good quality alkylates and the volumetric acid-to-hydrocarbon ratio (H/C) related to the interfacial area in the reaction system of 1:3, reaching a selectivity to C8 of 95%. The authors attributed this result to the solubility of isobutane in acid, whose acidity, in this case, remained constant. On the other hand, the optimum isobutane-to-olefin (I/O) molar ratio was 150, reaching C8 selectivity of up to 96%. Furthermore, the collected data indicate that high isobutane concentrations inhibit olefin polymerization reactions and high research octane numbers (RON). The suitable reaction time in this H2SO4/TFA system was 3.5 min, and as the reaction time increased, the selectivity to C8 decreased due to the augmented isobutane solubility; therefore, the mass transfer process required less time. ILs as catalysts of the alkylation reaction Although different alternative materials and chemicals have been explored as more environmentally ambiguous and less risky catalysts, ionic liquids appear to be the most promising alternative to replace the catalysts currently used for the alkylation reaction. In this section, the catalysts will be discussed according to their acidity type. Brønsted acidic ILs as catalyst of the alkylation reaction The need to improve the industrial I/O alkylation reaction has encouraged the efforts to develop Brønsted-acidic ILs (BAILs), which can be used in the alkylation of isobutane/2-butene [33]. Wang and co-workers prepared [N222H]+-type protic ILs by varying the acid ratio when used triethylammonium trifluoromethanesulfate [N222H]CF3SO3 and trimethylammonium hydrosulfate [N222H]HSO4. They were able to correlate the physicochemical properties of [N222H]CF3SO3/TfOH with the species and anion structure. Furthermore, these researchers studied and analyzed process variables, such as the relationship between catalyst and feed olefins, temperature, and time. It was concluded that [N222H]CF3SO3/TfOH with χTfOH = 0.69 was reusable for at least 36 times without significant loss of catalytic activity, which was attributable to the buffering effect of the anion groups, [N222H][CF3SO3(CF3SO3H)x] (x = 0,1,2). The selectivity to C8 was 86.23%, and the RON was equal to 97.3. In addition to its reusability, the new catalytic system had the advantage of showing better compatibility with impurities and was significantly less corrosive of both carbon and stainless-steel types than both pure sulfuric and triflic acids. The authors proposed that the acidity could be buffered by binding the solubilized acid in the anionic cluster form [CF3SO3(CF3SO3H)x] with (x = 0, 1, 2) [34]. Ammonium-based ILs have also been identified and synthesized by neutralization of amines with triflic acid (TfOH). The following ILs belong to this type of compounds: 2-hydroxy-N,N-dimethylpropan-1-ammonium hydrogen sulfate ([(iPrOH)Me2NH][HSO4]), N,N-dimethyl-N-ethanolammonium hydrogen sulfate ([(EtOH)Me2NH][HSO4]), N,N-dimethyl-N-ethanolammonium hydrogen sulfate ([(EtOH)Me2NH][HSO4]), ethanolammonium hydrogen sulfate ([EtOHNH3] [HSO4]), N,N-diethyl-N-ethanolammonium hydrogen sulfate ([(EtOH)Et2NH][HSO4]), N-methyl-N,N-diethanolammonium hydrogen sulfate ([(EtOH)2MeNH][HSO4]), triethylammonium hydrogen sulfate ([Et3NH][HSO4]). A reaction with triflic acid (CF3SO3H) was performed to obtain N-triflate, N-diethyl-N-ethanolammonium triflate ([(EtOH)Et2NH][CF3SO3]), 2-hydroxy-N,N-dimethylpropan-1-ammonium triflate ([(iPrOH)Me2NH][CF3SO3]), N-methyl-N,N-diethanolammonium triflate ([(EtOH)2MeNH][CF3SO3]) and triethylammonium triflate ([Et3NH][CF3SO3]) [35]. The catalytic capacity of these compounds was evaluated by identifying and confirming that the optimal ILs contents in the catalytic system were 15, 25, or 40 vol.% depending on the ILs structure [36]; in general, these chemical species mixed with CF3SO3H had good selectivity to C8 (between 87 and 92%) and high RON (96–98) with reaction temperature of 10 °C for 10 min. The authors considered that the good results were due to the excellent solubility of CF3SO3H in the ammonium ILs, minimizing the polymerization of 2-butene, and the alkylation results were better with CF3SO3 than with HSO4, highlighting that the [Et3NH][CF3SO3]/CF3SO3H system almost kept a constant acidity, changing the surface tension, viscosity, and density of TfOH, in addition, to be reused up to 36 times. ILs, including sulfonic acid groups, have been developed to allow proton transfer and thus achieve better conversions and selectivities to C8. In 2002, the synthesis of an HO3S-functionalized IL (SFIL) was reported, which was achieved through the alkylsulfonic acid group (anion) and imidazolium cation in the same chemical structure [37]. Fig. 4 shows an example of reaction to obtain SFIL. Among its properties, SFIL has been described as structurally flexible, non-volatile, non-corrosive, stable in water and air, and immiscible with various organic solvents. These ILs favor the alkylation of short-chain alkenes, then, good results could also be achieved with 1-(4-sulfonic acid)butyl-3-methylimidazolium triflate and 1-(4-sulfonic acid)butyl-3-butylimidazolium triflate [38], as alternative reaction media to conventional acid catalysts, with high conversion and excellent selectivity to C8 in the oligomerization of olefins [39]. Tang et al. [40] used 5 cations and 3 anions (Fig. 5 ) to synthesize six imidazolium-type BAIL: 1-hexyl-3-methyl-imidazolium bis(trifuoromethylsulfonyl)amide ([HMIM][Tf2N]), 1-octyl-3-methyl-imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([OMIM][HSO4], 3-(3-methyl-imidazoliumyl)propyl or butyl), 3-methyl-1-(3-sulfobutyl)-imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([MBSIM][HSO4]), 3-methyl-1-(3-sulfobutyl)-imidazolium trifluoro methylsulfonate ([MBSIM][OTf]) and 3-methyl-1-(3-sulfopropyl)-imidazolium trifluoromethylsulfonate ([MPSIM][OTf]). Adding [OMIM][HSO4] at 23 wt.% and CF3SO3H to the alkylation process of isobutane/2-butene, the conversion was improved up to 96% and C8 selectivity up to75%. As for H2SO4 and CF3SO3H, the selectivity to C8 was improved between 14 and 34.7%. The recycling study was carried out for the [OMIM][HSO4]/H2SO4 and [OMIM][HSO4]/CF3SO3H systems, where 8 and 25 cycles were obtained, respectively, representing better recycling than with pure H2SO4 and TfOH. Another family of ILs with imidazole as cation and hydrogen sulfonate as anion was synthesized by Cole's method [37,41], and the catalytic evaluation of five Acid/IL mixtures in the isobutane/2-butene alkylation reaction was compared to those of H2SO4 and TfOH without ILs; the alkylation reactions were performed at 15 °C and 1500 rpm (Table 1 ). The use of ILs with acid improves the TMP/DMH ratio compared to H2SO4 and CF3SO3H alone, standing out [EMIM][HSO4] and [Et3NH][HSO4]. The other 3 ILs had a lower TMP/DMH ratio, attributed to the steric hindrance in the chemical structure, preventing the coordination of 2-butene and cationic species and favoring the formation of more DMH. In other experiments, copper salts were added to compare the behavior displayed by the ILs. ILs of the type [CnPS/m][HSO4] were also reported, where n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8 [42] and were synthesized from N-alkyl-imidazole, 1,3-propylsultone, and H2SO4, generating a new SFIL/H2SO4 family. In this way, [MPSIM][HSO4], [EPSIM][HSO4], [BPSIM][HSO4], [HPSIm][HSO4] and [OPSIM][HSO4] were obtained (Fig. 6 ). The reaction time (25 min were suitable) and IL-to-acid ratio (the best was 10 wt.%) were optimized. Moreover, the SFIL catalytic performance was improved by increasing the alkyl chain length of the SFIL ([OPSIM][HSO4]/H2SO4 mixture), which contributed to the C8 selectivity up to 75.73% and RON up to 95.66. The improved catalytic performance could be attributed to the enhanced isobutane dispersion onto the SFIL with a longer alkyl chain, and it was further correlated with a characteristic nanostructured aggregation of longer alkyl chains, confirmed by Molecular Dinamic simulation, while quantum chemistry calculations confirmed that the cationic groups formed strong hydrogen bonds between H2SO4 and sulfonic acid. More importantly, the reusability of the SFIL/H2SO4 mixture could reach up to 22 runs, outperforming that of pure H2SO4. The reactions of BAIL were performed in small volumes (about 200 mL) in an autoclave; in general, the results indicated that the use of the H2SO4 catalyst with other compounds, either organic acids or ILs, in the isobutane/2-butene alkylation reaction, improved the conversion and selectivity to C8; in addition, it was possible to decrease the high H2SO4 volumes [43]. Xu et al. [44] prepared polyILs with two Brønsted acid sites through the one-pot reaction between polyetheramine (PEA), propanesultone, and trifluoroacetic acids (TfOH), thus obtaining a highly effective catalyst under mild reaction conditions (ambient conditions and time of 25 min, Fig. 7 ). By adjusting the catalyst acidity using a PEA-ILs/TfOH ratio of 70:30 (H o = - 9.74), a conversion of 98.2% and selectivity to C8 of 86.6% was obtained. Thus, the catalyst could be regenerated in water and reused thirteen times without decreasing its efficiency. In previous work, Yu et al. [45] described a similar polyIL synthesis strategy. In the case of polyethers-ILs/TfOH, which under optimal conditions (polyILs with polymerization degree n = 75, ILs/TfOH (v/v) = 5, reaction temperature of 60 °C, the reaction time of 30 min, and stirring rate of 800 rpm) produced alkylate gasoline with selectivity to C8 above 80%, from which about 95% corresponded to TMP; however, although the catalyst recycling was straightforward, its performance decreased gradually for the conversion and selectivity to TMP. Lewis acid ILs as catalysts of the alkylation reaction It is well known that Brøsted acidic ILs are excellent catalysts in alkylation reactions of aromatic compounds [46] and isobutene dimerization [47]. However, the acidity of these compounds is insufficient to achieve conversions and selectivities similar or higher than the reactions catalyzed with HF and H2SO4. For that reason, researchers have focused on developing ILs with higher acidity, such as those containing Lewis acid sites. In the presence of aluminum chloride, ILs derivatives of imidazolium halide have been used as catalysts in isobutane alkylation reactions with 2-butene [48]. It was observed that the acidity of the ILs depends significantly on the AlCl3 to imidazolium halide molar ratio. When the mole fraction (X) of AlCl3 was greater than 0.5, these compounds are called Lewis acidic ILs [12]. When the mole fraction X = 0.58, many Brønsted acid sites are also formed, responsible for the significant production of TMP. Strong Lewis acids, i.e. [Al2Cl7]–,can react with hydrogen atoms in the 2-position of an imidazolium ion to form Brønsted acids as shown in Equation (1) [49–51]. ILs consisting of bromine aluminum salts have shown higher acidity than the corresponding ones of chlorine-derived salts [52]. Yoo et al. [49] investigated the influence of the anion (Cl– Br– and I–) on the formation of [C8MIM]X-AlCl3 ILs and found that the formation of the [AlCl3Br] – anion had stronger acidity than the other formed anionic species. (1) [Al2Cl7]-+H+→[AlCl4]-+[AlHCl3]+ In this sense, additives have been used, improving the selectivity of the alkylation reaction, and producing alkylates with better quality than those obtained by using the same ILs without them. The efficiency of the additives was explained by the formation of Brønsted acids or complexes, making the catalytic system exhibit acidity or super acidity [53]. On the other hand, ILs with high acidity can increase polymerization and cracking reactions, and consequently, there is a decrease in yield and alkylate quality. Some BAILs are promising co-catalysts for H2SO4-catalyzed isobutane/butene alkylation because acidic Brønsted sites enhance the catalytic TMP selectivity and system stability [40,42,54–57]. Therefore, research has been conducted to adjust the acidity by adding electron-donating substances such as CuCl, benzene, and nitrogenated bases to improve the catalytic performance of ILs [58–60]. The acidic strength based on HCI in chloroaluminate ILs is much stronger than HF since it forms an anion of the AlCl4 −, [7] or Al2Cl7 − or Al3Cl10 − type, which depends on the relative amounts of AlCl3 [61]. Lewis acid catalyst (LAC) by chloroaluminate ILs (C+ Al2Cl7 −) or composite Lewis ionic liquid (CIL) (C+ AlMen+Cl4 + n −) can only be considered at the beginning of the catalytic process and under ideal conditions because with increasing HF formation, the concomitant deactivation of the system occurs, and a Brønsted acid catalysis system begins to be formed. Therefore, both routes must be considered in the description of the entire catalyst system (Lewis and Brønsted catalysis) [62]. The LAC activity is lost by sensitivity to moisture and oxygen-containing components and donor/acceptor interaction between Lewis acids and the polymer (or acid-soluble oil) formed during the alkylation process. Whereby, this catalytic process requires constant renewal through the continuous addition of either MeCIX To increase the Lewis acidity, or HCl or alkyl chloride to avoid rapid deactivation of the Brønsted acidity; this addition promotes the formation of solids, and it can completely stop the LAC deactivation [62–65]. Several works related to LAC with chloroaluminate ILs can be assembled by the molar ratio of AlCl3 to ILs or by the type of applied cations. For example, the relative amounts 55 and 67 mol% produced highly acidic Lewis chloroaluminate species, such as Al2Cl4 −, or Al2Cl7 − or Al3Cl10 − and as a result, better butene conversion and higher RON [6,58,66–68] were obtained due to the following mechanism (Fig. 8 ). Lewis and Brønsted acidic species were found in chloroaluminate ILs by 1H NMR, 27Al NMR, and IR analysis. The Brønsted acidic species were related to chlorohydroxyaluminate Al2Cl6OH−resonating at 97 ppm in the 27Al NMR spectrum [69]. Furthermore, based on IR spectroscopy, it was found that for [BMIM]Cl/AlCl3, the Lewis acidity increased in the following order: CuCl < FeCl3 < ZnCl5 < AlCl3 [70]. This same principle was used by Huang et al. [71] when preparing ILs based on triethylamine hydrochloride/aluminum (III) chloride, according to the mole ratio of 1:2, achieving butene conversion up to 97%, C8 selectivity up to 50.4%, and TMP/DMH up to 3.0. In addition, CILs were prepared by adding CuCl, ZnCl2, NiCl2, and SnCl4 at about 5% to 1 mole of AlCl3 to determine the metal chloride effect on alkylation. Only cuprous chloride positively affected the alkylation process, increasing the C8 selectivity to 74.8% and the TMP/DMH ratio to 6.5. The CILs based on chloroaluminate and cuprous chloride showed super TMP selectivity, and the RON was higher than 100 under the optimal conditions: reaction temperature 20 °C, I/O ratio = 15, and reaction time from 5 to 10 min [72]. Chloroaluminate ILs can be modified with transition metal salts, metal complexes, and metal oxides (CuCl, CuCl2, AgCl, ZnCl2, NiCl2, CeCl3, SnCl2, ZnO, CuO, Tb4O7, and CeO2), forming CILs. Under reaction conditions such as initial I/O = 7:1, 30 °C, stirring = 1150 rpm, 15 mL of IL and 5 g of additive, the ILs [Et3NH]Cl-AlCl3/CuAlCl4 possessed the best alkylate quality (RON = 100.5). The TMP selectivity of the modified ILs could be attributed to the formation of complexes between 2-butene and transition metals. Although the transition metal compound cannot significantly change the acid strength of the ILs, it can increase the I/O ratio of the reaction system [73]. An attempt was also made to apply in isobutane alkylation, not only CILs based on alkylamines, but also chloroaluminate eutectic ILs based on amide (formamide, acetamide, urea, and methyl urea) with both Brønsted and Lewis acidities. Again, the cuprous chloride CILs based on urea/1.6 AlCl3 with 0.13 CuCl displayed the best catalytic performance. The butene conversion was about 99.9%, C8 selectivity reached 57.6%, and the RON was 91. Moreover, this catalyst could be reused 20 times without any pronounced decrease in catalytic performance: 15 °C, stirring rate of 1500 rpm, hydrocarbon feeding rate of 300 mL/h, I/O molar ratio of 15:1, and reaction time of 15 min [74]. Hu et al. [75] also synthesized and evaluated a group of amide-AlCl3-based ILs (acetamide, N-methylacetamide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, and N-methylformamide) that contained CuCl in their structure. N-methylacetamide-AlCl3 (ratio = 0.75/1.0) modified with CuCl showed improved catalytic performance with C8 selectivity up to 94.65 wt.%, in which the TMP/DMHs molar ratio and alkylate RON reached 14.98 and 98.40, respectively. This efficiency can be attributed to low viscosity, high isobutane solubility, and capacity to build a Lewis coordination structure, which improves the hydrogen transfer between the C8 +cation and isobutane. In search of ILs with the same Lewis acidity as chloroaluminates (III) but more resistant to hydrolysis, chlorogallate (III) ILs were tested in the isobutane/butene alkylation reaction. The [Et3NH]Cl/0.65 GaCl3 showed potential catalytic activity, but the addition of 5 mol% of CuCl to the system allowed to reach up to 70.1% of C8 selectivity and 91.3 RON under the following conditions: 0.5 MPa, 900 rpm, 15 min, 15 °C using the industrial C4 cut (isobutane/butene = 10), 40 mL of hydrocarbon feed and 16 mL of catalyst. Additionally, these ILs could be reused 9 cycles in batch mode without significant activity loss [76]. Despite the excellent performance of the CILs with CuCl, a question remains, where the effects of CuCl, HCl, and H2O are still not fully understood, mainly that exerted by CuCl on the selectivity. An attempt was made to use other additives for chloroaluminate ILs instead of metal salts or oxides to increase catalytic activity and selectivity; such additives have been aromatic compounds like benzene and toluene. As a consequence, using [Et3NH]Cl/2.0 AlCl3 with a benzene mixture (1%) increased the C8 selectivity up to 90.1, as well as the TMP:DMH ratio in the alkylate at low temperature (15 °C). In addition, this catalyst performance can be easily maintained by reloading benzene [77]. In situ NMR, IR, Raman characterizations, molecular dynamics simulation, and ADCH analysis showed that benzene could enrich the acid–hydrocarbon interface and that π−H bonds could be formed between benzene and the ILs, significantly affecting the charge transfer of alkanes and chloroaluminate anions. Due to these weak interactions, the aromatic–ion interaction inhibited the polymerization side reactions and promoted the hydride transfer from isobutane to C8 +. Traditional imidazolium and pyridinium chloroaluminate ILs are unsuitable for industrial applications because of their high cost, poor biodegradability, more complex preparation and low internal mass transfer. Therefore, it is necessary to use a better drop dispersion technique to obtain drops less than 400 μm of hydrocarbon. For example, the effectiveness factor for the utilization of [BMIM]Cl/0.64 AlCl3 droplets is low and near 4%, in addition to its external mass transfer resistance (82%) [78]. Promoters such as tert-butyl halides can help improve the performance of the [BMIM]Cl/0.64 AlCl3 ILs, showing high activity and TMP-selectivity; therefore, in a continuous mode, the 2-butene conversion was approximately 20–30% for a 0.2 mol% promoter concentration (tert-butyl halides) and 55–60% for 0.4 mol% of the promoter. However, the distribution of the final product is dominated by a high percentage of C9 and C10. The deactivation of the LAC system leads to isobutene release and its polymerization reactions [66]. The addition of butyl thioalcohol to [BMIM]Cl/0.64 AlCl3 improved the alkylate product quality with 2-butene conversion up to 99%, and the TMP/DMH ratio was 6.6 at low reaction temperature (30 °C) with high isobutane to 2-butene ratio (equal to 10), and 40 min of reaction time [79]. Another promoter is obtained when benzene is enriched in the acid-hydrocarbon interfacial layer. According to the molecular dynamic simulation, the improvement of the C4 alkylation performance is that benzene molecules would buffer the super acidity of anions in that region [60]. Based on the solvation-diffusion mechanism, isobutane solubility and diffusion in the chloroaluminate imidazolium ILs were estimated. It showed that the ILs with longer alkyl chains have better performance in the following order: [BMIM]Al2Cl7 > [OMIM]AlCl4 > [HMIM]AlCl4 > [BMIM]AlCl4 [80]. Brønsted-Lewis dual acidic ILs in the isobutane alkylation reaction There are many research works where ILs holding both Brønsted and Lewis acidity have been prepared in order to work as catalysts in different chemical reactions, e.g., dimerization of rosin [81], Beckmann rearrangement [82], catalytic conversions of biomass-derived carbohydrates into added-value chemicals [83], esterifications, biomass conversion [84], biodiesel production from soapberry oil [85] or waste oil [86], catalysis of cellulose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [87], hydrolysis of cellulose [88], toluene carbonylation reaction [89], and acetalization and Michael addition reactions [90], among others. In addition to the strategies to overcome the low stability of ILs containing chloroaluminate anions, the synthesis of ILs exhibiting functionality with Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites, the so-called dual ILs, has been carried out. Liu et al. [91] investigated dual ILs in fatty acid methyl ester dimerization in this context. The Brønsted-Lewis acidic ILs consisted of (3-sulfonic acid)-propyl-triethylammonium chloride [HO3SC3NEt3]Cl in combination with some transition metal chlorides (FeCl3, ZnCl2, CuCl, and CuCl2) (X = 0.64 to X = 0.75). One of the observed results was that the dual Brønsted-Lewis ILs were inert in air and moisture and, as a consequence, had better catalytic performance than a traditional catalytic system. Also, Liu et al. [92] investigated the alkylation of isobutane/butene using dual ILs derived from [HO3SC3NEt3]Cl in combination with metal salts (ZnCl2, CuCl2, CuCl FeCl3, and AlCl3). The best result showed 100% of isobutane conversion and the selectivity to alkylated C8 reached 97.1% with a TMP/DMH ratio of 75%. (Table 2 , entry 1). This outcome was obtained when using [HO3SC3NEt3]Cl-ZnCl2 ILs, which had dual acidity (Fig. 9 ) under the following conditions: feed = 13 g, isobutane/isobutene molar ratio = 10:1, catalyst mass = 3.0 g, X (Lewis acidic metal chloride) = 0.83, H2O = 1.3 g, T = 60 °C, t = 2 h. The result was attributed to a synergistic effect exerted by both acid sites, which increased the catalytic activity, and therefore, bettered the conversion and selectivity of the alkylation reaction. In order to determine the occurrence of this synergy, the ILs in their Brønsted [HO3SC3NEt3]Cl, Table 2, entry 2) and Lewis ([Et3NH]Cl-ZnCl2, Table 2, entry 3) forms were used separately in the reaction. TMP selectivity was 44.7 and 49.6%, respectively, representing poorer efficiency than with the dual ILs. The addition of water to the reaction had a promoting effect, as observed by comparing entries 4 and 1 in Table 2. When no water was used, the conversion was only 45.2%. On the other hand, the reaction did not occur when water was added to the [HO3SC3NEt3]Cl-AlCl3 ILs, which can be ascribed to the moisture sensitivity of AlCl3, thus losing the both Brønsted and Lewis acid centers. Another important aspect was the ability to reuse the ILs up to 10 times, with practically no decrease in conversion and selectivity concerning fresh ILs. Finally, the ability to use the dual ILs in several reaction cycles was attributed to the sulfonic groups covalently bound to the cation, and the Lewis acid centers are stable in the presence of water or alkyl sulfonic group. In another investigation, Liu et al. [93] reported on the use of dual ILs derived from 1-(3-sulfonic acid)-propyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ILs [HO3SC3MIM]Cl in combinations with metal chlorides (ZnCl2, FeCl2, FeCl3, CuCl2, CuCl, and AlCl3), under the following conditions: feed = 11.3 g, iso-butane/iso-butene molar ratio = 10:1, catalyst mass = 3.0 g, X (Lewis acidic metal chloride) = 0.67, H2O = 1.3 g, T = 80 °C and t = 4 h. A similar effect was observed in their previous work [92]. That is, a synergistic effect by the presence of Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites resulted in a conversion close to 100% and TMP selectivity of 80.5% (Table 2, entry 6), which were much higher than the respective ILs containing only Brønsted or Lewis acidic sites, obtaining conversions of 51.3 and 66%, and TMP selectivities of 64.7 and 64.1%, respectively (Table 2, entries 7 and 8). When different metal chlorides were used to catalyze the alkylation reactions, it was observed that these metal salts remarkably affected the catalytic performance. In this case, ILs [HO3SC3NEt3]Cl-ZnCl2 displayed the best performance compared to the other dual-acidic ILs holding FeCl2, FeCl3, CuCl2, CuCl, and AlCl3 salts. This result was attributed to the difference in the ILs acidic strength, which is responsible for protonating 2-butene protonation. Increasing the Lewis acidity of the metal chloride makes the total acidity stronger, increasing the ILs catalytic activity [94]. When no water was added to the dual-acidic ILs, poorer performance in terms of conversion (66.8%) and selectivity (72.3%) (Table 2, entry 9) was obtained, in comparison to the dual-acidic ILs with 30% of added water (Table 2, entry 6). The molar ratio of the metal salt in the ILs was monitored from X Z n C l 2  = 0.5–0.75. The conversion increased up to 100% when the molar ratio of the metal salt was increased. However, from X Z n C l 2  = 0.71, the selectivity to TMP started to decrease. The optimal molar ratio was X Z n C l 2  = 0.67. The ILs [HO3SC3MIM]Cl-ZnCl2 (X = 0.67) was reused up to seven times without a decrease in reaction conversion and product selectivity (Fig. 10 ). Bui et al. [95] investigated the alkylation of isobutane with 2-butene using the ILs 1-n-octyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide-aluminum chloride ([OMIM]Br-AlCl3), pure and in mixture with other components as catalysts, such as 1-(4-sulfobutyl)−3-methylimidazolium hydrogensulfate ([(HO3SBu)MIM]HSO4) (Fig. 11 ), under the following conditions: 5 °C, 600 kPa, time = 60 min, iso-butane/iso-butene ratio = 10:1. When the IL [OMIM]Br-AlCl3 was used as catalyst, aluminum chloride's best-found molar ratio was X = 0.6, and the TMP content was 22 wt.%, with an octane number of 91. When 90 ppm of water was added, the TMP content increased to 50 wt.%, and the fraction of C9+ dropped from 65 to 15 wt.%. If the IL [(HO3SBu)MIM]HSO4 is used as an additive, 53 wt.% of TMP yield was achieved with the corresponding RON of 95. The increase in reaction performance was attributed to the reaction between ILs [OMIM]Br-AlCl3 and the sulfonic groups found in ILs [(HO3SBu)MIM]HSO4, which allowed the formation of super acidic species. The reusability of the ILs was explored through eleven sequential runs, and the alkylate composition and RON were reduced very little after ten cycles. The water presence did not result in the deactivation of the catalyst (Fig. 11). Wang et al. [74] researched deep eutectic ILs based on amide-aluminum chloride synthesized using formamide (FA), acetamide (AA), urea, and methyl urea (Me-urea) as the amide substrates which exhibited both Lewis and Brønsted acidities. The effect of different catalysts on the alkylation activity such as that of the AlCl3/amide molar ratio, metal additive, and that of the reaction conditions using the deep eutectic ILs Urea-1.6AlCl3–0.13CuCl, temperature, stirring rate, hydrocarbon feeding rate, I/O molar ratio, reaction time, and the effect of the butene source and recyclability were studied. When metal additives (such as CuCl, FeCl3, ZnCl2, and SnCl2) and the dual-acidic ILs, were used, a synergistic effect on the catalytic process was observed. For example, the ILs modified with CuCl salt and Urea-1.6AlCl3–0.13CuCl (AlCl3/Urea, 1.6:1) displayed an outstanding catalytic performance, which could be attributed to the formation of chlorinated aluminum-copper coordination species of AlCuCl2 – and Al2CuCl3 – in the catalytic system, compared to the reaction system that did not use the copper salt (Table 2, entry 12). The butene conversion was about 99.9%, the C8 selectivity reached 57.6%, and RON was 91 (Table 2, entry 11). The Urea-1.6AlCl3–0.13CuCl IL could be reused up to 20 times without any decrease in its catalytic performance under the following conditions: 15 °C reaction temperature, stirring rate of 1500 rpm, hydrocarbon feeding rate of 300 mL/h, I/O molar ratio of 15:1, and reaction time of 15 min. An essential difference regarding the present study was that all of the dual amide-aluminum chloride ILs were used without water in the reaction system. Therefore, the most direct comparison could be between entries 4, 9, 11, and 12 (Table 2), where the conversions/selectivities were 42.5/88.6, 66.8/72.3, 99.9/57.6, and 97.1/32.3, respectively. Supported ILs as catalysts of the alkylation reaction Supported ILs (SILs) are materials where the ILs phase is anchored to an inorganic solid or polymeric support. In the first case, immobilization occurs depending on the interaction between the ILs components (cations or anions) and the support material or active group. The most important benefit of having an IL fixed on a solid surface lies in that the advantages of ILs such as non-volatility and high solvent capacity are combined with those of heterogeneous materials such as easy separation, reusability, lower catalyst loading, besides their additional chemical properties like Brønsted or Lewis acidity and metallic behavior. There are three ways to immobilize an ILs on an inorganic solid surface, as shown in Fig. 12 . The first is an immobilization via the anion (Fig. 12a), where the inorganic support reacts with an active metal salt that acts as the counter ion of the cationic organic moiety;; the second one via the cation (Fig. 12b), where the imidazolium moiety holding reactive Si-OR groups react with the OH groups of the support, thus forming covalent bonds with the cation, and via a supported liquid phase, where the Si-OR groups react with a silicon source via sol-gel method, generating direct Si-C bonds on a silica surface (Fig. 12c) [96]. This direct immobilization is named physical confinement or encapsulation method, since no acid functional groups within the ILs or reactions with the support are needed, and the products have more possible freedom degrees. There is a significant range of applications of these materials; however, their use in catalysis dominates the others. Their most reported use is in the Friedel Crafts alkylation, CO2 fixation and CC coupling reactions, esterification, and oxidations. Their use in the isobutane/butene alkylation reaction has not been extended so far [96,97]. As for the fixation of ILs on polymers, their synthesis methods and applications fall out of this scoping review. Therefore, the reader is directed to the respective bibliography [98,99]. However, the first application of a polymeric ILs in the isobutane/butene alkylation was reported by the Nobel prize recipient G. Olah in 2005 [26], where the application of poly(HF)-based liquid and solid materials as catalysts was carried out in an attempt to avoid the application of the single HF as in many of the current chemical processes. In that report, fluorinated ILs were generated from the reaction of HF with poly(ethyleneimine) by the reaction between HF with pyridine (Fig. 13 ). The poly ILs were tested in their behavior towards isobutane/butene alkylation using the typical HF-based conditions, and the results were not satisfactory, yielding high octane C8-hydrocarbons; however, when using the PVPHF polymer (Fig. 13b), which results from the reaction between poly(4-vinyl pyridine) and HF, the outcome was completely opposite, because a molar ratio of HF/pyridine = 22:1 could reach up to 44.4 wt.% of 2,2,4-TMP with a total C8-hydrocarbon yield of 74.4% and a RON of 93 within 3 min, using an I/O molar ratio of 12 at 36 °C. Such results are very close to those obtained with HF alone, but there was no risk of HF leakage in this case, and the catalyst showed excellent stability and activity up to 4 reaction cycles; then, the RON decreased due to the slow leaching of HF from the catalyst. This system surpassed the H2SO4-based process by far, and the patent is the basis of the UOP Alkad process [100]. The first approximation to the isobutane/butene alkylation using immobilized imidazolium-based catalysts occurred in 2006 by Kumar [101]. In their report, two solid catalysts were prepared by immobilization via anion (NLAC I, Fig. 14 a) and via cation (NLAC II, Fig. 14b). The new Lewis acids, as named, were active in the alkylation of a real raffinate composed by an I/O molar ratio of 0.6 or diluted mixtures with compositions of 10, 20, and 110. Temperature and time of reactions were studied for NLAC I, turning out that the optimal conditions to obtain the highest yield of C8-hydrocarbons were 70 °C and 20 min of reaction. A study of the effect on yield, conversion, and selectivity of alkylate in the presence of NLAC II showed that the higher the alkene concentration, the higher the yield and selectivity to C8-hydrocarbons, although a threshold limit where high ends (HEs) started to increase at the expense of low ends (LEs) was reached. A comparison of solid catalysts yielded that NLAC II showed better yield and selectivity than other solid acids such as Beta zeolite or a Nafion-silica nanocomposite, and the outcome was comparable to that of H2SO4. Among liquid catalysts, imidazolium-based ILs have displayed better performance than phosphonium-based ILs at the expense of the reaction time. Unfortunately, when attempting to reuse the catalyst, the catalytic activity was sustained for only 2 reaction cycles, most probably due to the decomposition of the moisture-sensitive chloroaluminate anion. Later on, two reports by Jin et al. [102,103] were published regarding IL immobilization to study the adsorption modulation of mixtures of olefins/paraffin as potential catalysts for potential alkylation reactions. In the first report, immobilization via the cation of 3-sulfonatebutyl-1-triethoxypropyl-imidazolium hydrogen sulfate was carried out on MCM-22 (Fig. 15 a), and in the second report, three 1-alkyl-3-triethoxypropyl-imidazolium hydrogen sulfates (alkyl = methyl, ethyl, butyl; Fig. 15b) were fixed on the same support. In the initial study with IL-MCM22–1, ethane/ethylene mixtures were adsorbed on the solid surface, and the adsorbed ratio increased about 30%, which means that more ethane was adsorbed at the expense of ethylene. Later on, the study was extended to 3 ILs with 3 different alkyl chains (ILs-MCM22–2, 3, and 4), where similar results were obtained. Here, a more concise study of the effect of the ILs was given, stating that by lowering the polarity through the ILs’ alkyl chain, the number of acid sites to interact with the olefin is decreased, yielding a less polar environment, generating more affinity towards paraffin. Furthermore, the authors found no influence of the alkyl chain on the preferential selectivity towards any hydrocarbon, but the number of acid sites was essential in the selectivity towards olefins rather than paraffin. This investigation should serve as a milestone in determining the best alkylation conditions in the upcoming research on supported ILs. When using MCM-22 as support, the main issue is the highly damaging effect of the ILs on the surface area and pore size, reducing the adsorption capacity of the solid significantly. To address this problem, Li et al. [104] reported on the use of MCM-36, which was synthesized from MCM-22 as a precursor to immobilize 1-butyl-3-trietoxysilylpropyl-imidazolium hydrogen sulfate ([BTPIm][HSO4], Fig. 16 ), using essentially the same procedure as that by Jin et al. [102]. The results confirmed that the IL-modified support enhanced the solid interaction with the paraffin at its expense the expense of the olefin, which was the beneficial effect of higher hydrophobicity caused by the non-polar hydrocarbon branch of the IL. However, the total hydrocarbon adsorption capacity was lower than that of the original MCM-22 support due to the greatly pronounced decrease in surface area and pore volume. Notwithstanding, the introduction of a grafted acidic IL is beneficial to the increase in the I/O adsorption ratio, because of the change in surface features, microstructure, and wettability of the support. Although the excellent properties of supported ILs have widely been known, their application in the alkylation reaction has been scarcely carried out. It was not until very recent years that the research was retaken by Liu et al. [105], whose report in 2019 showed the immobilization of an ILs on mesoporous MCM-41 in a similar fashion to that of Kumar's. However, in this case, the newly heterogeneous catalyst was enhanced by adding sulfated zirconia (SZ) to the inorganic porous frame (ILs/SZ@MCM-41, Fig. 17 ). The newly obtained catalyst showed higher selectivity towards TMP and C8-hydrocarbons during the isobutane-butene alkylation reaction than obtained with H2SO4, MCM-41, free ILs, SZ, and SZ-MCM-41 under the same conditions, proving that a synergistic effect between SZ and ILs is effected within the catalyst structure. Besides a significant reduction in the surface area and pore volume, according to XRD and NMR results, there was no noticeable change in the support structure after immobilizing the organic and inorganic moieties. Doping of the catalyst structure with Cu, Zn, and Ce was carried out, and the Zn dopped catalyst (IL/SZ-Zn@MCM-41) showed outstanding behavior, improving the selectivity towards TMP of original IL/SZ@MCM-41 (from 63 to 74%), owing to an enhancement of the catalyst mesoporosity by Zn atoms, yielding a much more efficient shape selectivity. Finally, experiments using a continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR) produced a higher I/O feed ratio, which in turn enhanced the efficiency of the catalytic activity of ILs/SZ-Zn@MCM-41 by increasing the selectivity towards TMP from 74 to 84%, obtaining a final RON of 98.5; such efficiency was sustained for up to 240 min. However, the activity was lost with extended time due to the gradual acidity decrease provoked by the leaching of ILs from the solid support. Later on, in 2020, Liu et al. [106] reported an attempt to use the same catalyst system (ILs/SZ@MCM-41) in a rotating packed bed reactor (RPB) for isobutane/butene reactions. In this case, the results of IL/SZ@MCM-41 and SZ used independently as solid acids were very similar. Unfortunately, the results of IL/SZ@MCM-41 were not satisfactory in terms of TMP and RON yields; therefore, instead of using the immobilized catalyst, both IL and SZ were charged into the reactor separately but acting at the same time. Applying the optimized conditions of I/O of 7:1 and H/C volume ratio of 1, 1200 rpm at 5 °C, the TMP and alkylate RON obtained were 87.1 and 99.8, respectively. In addition, the increase in the acid-hydrocarbon interfacial area played a crucial role in enhancing the catalyst activity by reducing the droplet size and improving contact between acid sites and olefin. Recently, low toxicity Lewis acidic ILs supported in halloysite nanoclay have been developed that could offer novel alternatives as catalysts for the reaction to obtain alkylation gasoline [107]. The supported ILs as isobutane/butene alkylation catalysts can be considered as a newborn field. Even if just isolated efforts have been performed, the modulation of the catalyst chemical functionalities on the ILs to confer them higher acidity (e.g., by holding both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites) has enhanced the effective carbocation formationWhile tuning the acidity and textural properties of the support has allowed better shape selectivity towards TMP, the use of additives and new reactor technologies to enhance the interphase properties has been essentially unexplored. Fig. 18 shows a hypothetical improved ILs holding both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites supported on strong acid and porous zeolite, which might be the case study in future ILs research for isobutane/butene alkylation, along with the support's afore-mentioned properties and reactor technologies, which are crucial in the quest of highly active and selective catalysts. Additives in catalysts based on ILs There are several procedures to increase the activity of ILs as catalysts in the isobutane alkylation reaction to produce TMP: a) adding organic and inorganic additives adjusts the system acidity by appropriate amounts of a Brønsted acid (e.g., HCl, H2O) or a functional group such as −SO3H; b) the formation of tert‑butyl carbocations is promoted when alkyl halides such as tert‑butyl chloride and tert‑butyl bromide are added, significantly accelerating the reaction rate and increasing the selectivity towards TMP (alkyl halides can promote the ILs-catalyzed alkylation of the Lewis acid chloroaluminate [108]; c) ILs can be structurally redistributed by introducing transition metal salts (CuCl, CuCl2, and NiCl2) [108], which also inhibits the by-products formation and improve the alkylate qualities [48,79]. The effects of butyl‑thioalcohol and ethyl-thioether additives on the properties of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium-aluminum chloride have been investigated. On the one hand, butyl-thioalcohol modified the TMP selectivity, which was increased from 37.3% for pure ILs to 65.9% with additives. This effect is attributed to the electron donation capacity of the sulfur atom and the formation of a new Brønsted acid site [HC4H8]+ AlCl4 − in the presence of the thioalcohol additive, which dampens the adequate acidity level of the ILs to reduce secondary reactions. On the other hand, the results of a thioether additive regarding TMP selectivity were similar to those obtained with pure [BMIM]Cl-2AlCl3 system [79]. The effects of benzene as an additive in chloroaluminate were studied by Zhang et al. [77]. They found that the TMP content was increased up to 70 wt.%, with the addition of benzene. In this system, which led to the formation of a complex of Lewis acid sites with the π cloud of the aromatic ring was found. As a result, the modification of the electronic properties of the Lewis acid sites favored the alkylation reaction by inhibiting secondary reactions. Based on these results, Liu et al. [60] studied the effects of aromatic hydrocarbons such as benzene, toluene, m-xylene, trimethylbenzene, and hexaethylbenzene mixed with [BMIM][AlCl4] and triethylamine hydrochloride tetrachloroaluminate ([(C2H5)3NH][AlCl4]) on the alkylation yield of isobutane and 2-butene in 100-mL and 2 L reactors. The obtained results showed that when 5 wt.% of aromatics were added to [BMIM][AlCl4], RON and TMP increased, obtaining the best results hexaethylbenzene, reporting up to 85.5 wt.% of TMP and a RON of 98.7. Likewise, through a theoretical study, it was considered that the addition of aromatics modified the charge distributions of the interface atoms, increasing the dispersion of isobutane and accumulation of benzene molecules in the acid-hydrocarbon layer, in addition to reducing the super acidity of the anions in that region, causing an improvement of the C4 alkylation. Through experimental methods and theoretical calculations, Wu et al. [58] determined that aromatic compounds interact with chloroaluminate ions and form Ar-AlCl4, Ar-Al2Cl7- and [Ar-H]+ species. This new species buffer the acidity, but according to the results obtained from the theoretical study, aromatics were enriched at the H/C interface, and with an adequate charge transfer, they can affect the alkylation. Furthermore, this interaction inhibits secondary polymerization reactions, promoting the transfer of one isobutane hydride to C8 +. As for inorganic additives, the addition of metal salts, to change the acidity, which affects the formation of the t‑butyl cation (t-C4 +) in chloroaluminate ILs, causes interaction between metal cations and chloroaluminate anions, e.g., Cu (I) could replace the proton in the cation [(C2H5)3NH] +, generating [(C2H5)3N-Cu]+ and HCl. This interaction was studied by Pang et al. [109], who determined and quantified the ions formed in correlation with the changes in Lewis acidity and their relationship with catalytic selectivity through the values of the Gutmann acceptor number (AN) by 31P NMR. In the C8 alkylation, the AN value was proposed to decrease first when adding CuCl to the [(C2H5)3NH]Cl-AlCl3 system, and then, it increased. This mechanism is carried out according to the following reactions: (2) Al2Cl- 7+CuCL↔CuAlCl- 5+AlCl3 (3) [(C2H5)3NH]+AlCl- 4+CuCl↔[(C2H5)3NH]]CuAlCl- 5 (4) Al2Cl- 7+Cl↔2AlCl- 4 (5) tepo+AlCl3→tepo-AlCl3 When the molar ratio of CuCl concerning AlC l 3 is greater than 0.5. The AN value for ILs increases due to the following reactions: (6) [(C2H5)3NH]+AlCl- 4+CuCl→[(C2H5)3NCu]++AlCl- 4+HCl (7) tepo-AlCl3+AlCl- 4+Cu+↔tepo-2AlCl3+CuCl The TMP and RON results are presented in Table 3 . In this study, it was concluded that [(C2H5)3NH]Cl–AlCl3 CuCl seems to have more Lewis acidity than [(C2H5)3NH]Cl/AlCl3. Patent US2017/0320047A1 reported the IL Et3NHCl/AlCl3 with the CuCl additive at various concentrations. The advantage of using this complex was reducing the formation of solids during alkylation, and the concentration ratio that produced the best performance was 1Et3NHCl/1.8AlCl3/0.4 CuCl, reporting RON and TMP of 98.1 and 83.3%, respectively. Furthermore, the results showed that a lower amount of CuCl related to the IL results in lower selectivity to TMP and alkylate RON [110]. With the same procedure, the influence of the CuCl additive on Et3NHCl was studied. As for this IL with anhydrous AlCl3, the resulting IL complex showed efficient catalytic performance under the following reaction conditions: 15 °C temperature, time = 20 s, ILs to hydrocarbon volume ratio = 1:1 and isobutane to olefin molar ratio = 54:1, obtaining a butene conversion of 100%; the selectivity to C8 and TMP were 88.9 and 82.0%, respectively; the RON was 97.3. This work concluded that, by adding the additive CuCl to chloroaluminates, a new complexed Al-Cu anion is formed, which can inhibit side reactions due to an increase in the density of Brønsted acid sites and a decrease in the density of Lewis acid sites. The acidic Brønsted sites suppress side reactions such as cracking, polymerization and isomerization, and therefore, they modify the selectivity to TMP [111]. The IL 0.55 Et3NHCl –1.0AlCl3–0.28CuCl modified with a molar ratio of 0.75 of N-methylacetamide improved the catalytic activity, C8 selectivity, and RON, reaching 94.65 wt.% and 98.40%, respectively, attributing such selectivity to the CuCl species because it is bonded to the analog compound, that is, the ILs with additive, which is lost in the process. The optimal reaction conditions were the following: isobutane / 2-butene molar ratio of 100: 1, reaction temperature of 15 °C, stirring rate of 1500 rpm and reaction time of 30 s. In addition, NMR helped identify the Al species as the primary acidity source [112]. Table 3 shows the selectivity towards TMP of different pure ILs, and the results in presence of different additives is contrasted. As can be seen in Table 3, in general, the use of additives improves the performance of ILs in alkylation reactions. Likewise, as previously discussed, CILs used with different metal salts improve the performance of ILs when used as conventional Lewis acids, i.e., those containing only one single metal. The CILs obtained from aluminum and copper salts show particularly high conversion and selectivity to TMP and the RON of the alkylated gasoline obtained is increased. Similarly, the addition of small amounts of water and aromatic organic additives such as benzene, toluene, xylene, and analogs significantly improve the performance of Lewis acid-type CILs. Technology developments for alkylate gasoline using ILs Some alternatives to the traditional HF/H2SO4 alkylation processes have been proposed for environmental and industrial safety reasons, and these will be discussed in this section. To start with, two technological strands have been put in place, e.g., Chevron installed at the Salt Lake City refinery the first ILs-based alkylation unit capable of producing 5000 barrels of alkylate per day, while another alkylation process based on ILs has been developed at the China University of Petroleum and licensed by the Canadian firm Well Resources, which has installed six units in China, the most recent with a capacity to produce 7500 barrels per day of alkylate located in Wuhan [113]. Isoalky™ technology The Chevron and Honeywell UOP companies have developed a catalytic process that uses chloroaluminate ILs to obtain alkylate gasoline [114]. This is a crucial component of the gasoline blend used in internal combustion engines. The composition of the gasoline pool varies per region and this is between 12 and 20 vol.%. Its use is expected to increase over the next 10 years. The traditional methods for producing alkylate gasoline use sulfuric acid or hydrofluoric acid as catalysts; from all existing plants, 50% use either technology. Although there are reports or patents on the developement of solid catalysts or composites with ILs, their long-term behavior is unknown. A timeline showing the evolution of Chevron Isoalky technology research and development is shown in Fig. 19 . The company began its research and development program using ILs for the alkylation of olefinic streams in 2004. The first bench-scale plant was constructed to obtain 0.1 barrels per day (BPD). In 2005, studies of continuous operation, alkylation chemistry, optimization, separation, regeneration, and product post-treatment processes were carried out in such plant. In 2006, the construction of a 10-BPD demonstration plant began and was completed in 2009. Thus, for 5 years, process and design data, along with fundamental knowledge for the optimization of the continuous process, which is the heart of the Isoalky technology, were obtained. In 2021, a press release was issued in which Chevron and Honeywell announced the start-up of the world's first commercial Isoalky ILs Alkylation Unit [115]. The Isoalky technology is based on the transformation processes given in Equations 8–10: (8) iC4+C= 4→C8alkylate (9) iC4+C= 3→C7alkylate (10) iC4+C= 5→C9alkylate Fig. 20 describes the Isoalky technology process, consisting of an isobutane feed and the C3-C5 olefin charge coming from the FCC unit. There are conventional stages within the process, such as those of feed treatment and the distillation units, and completely new stages, such as that of alkylation reaction stage, the separation unit of the reaction products, and the regeneration of the chloroaluminate ILs-based catalyst. There are also complementary stages, such as organic chlorine addition and catalyst regeneration. The Isoalky technology uses a co-catalyst containing trace amounts of anhydrous HCl added in situ via an organic chloride and an anhydrous Lewis acid-based on AlCl3, considered as a superacid. The general formula of the ILs used in this process can be denoted as Q+A−. Table 4 shows the possible combinations of their composition [116], where Q+ is an ammonium or phosphonium cation and A− is an anion. Some examples of this group can be: quaternary amine chloroaluminate, hydrogen chloride chloroaluminate, hydrocarbyl-substituted pyridinium (or imidazolium) chloroaluminate, among others. Additional to these examples, the studies found that the compounds phosphonium-ILs and gallium chloride-based ILs catalysts were effective in the alkylation process. The Isoalky amine-based alkylation process requires a highly acid catalyst. Maximum catalytic activity and long-term stability are achieved when the molar ratio is 2:1 of AlCl3 to amine chloride. A continuous supply of the HCl co-catalyst is necessary to maintain such activity, which is achieved by adding an organic chlorine promoter. Essential studies of the fundamental aspects of the nature of chloroaluminate ILs were carried out by Ma and Johnson [117]. Additionally, their solubility and electrochemical profiles as a function of pressure were studied by Campbell and Johnson [118]. In turn, Smith et al. [7] studied the super acidity of these ILs. The isobutane/butene alkylation process using Lewis acid catalysts based on ILs co-catalyzed with HCl was studied by Jess et al. [66,78,119]. Wang et al. [35] published an interesting review of the alkylation process based on ILs as an alternative for the clean production of fuels. Some variants to these catalysts have been proposed by Liu et al. [108] and Cui et al. [69], consisting of CuCl or trialkyl ammonium hydrochloride. The properties of ILs make them very suitable to be used in refinery facilities, and since they have almost zero vapor pressure, any spillage can be easily controlled. Due to their low solubility in hydrocarbons, their separation is relatively simple through distillation processes. Typical personal protective equipment in refinery facilities is sufficient, and it is not necessary to implement specialized equipment such as that used for handling HF. However, as the Isoalky catalyst is highly hydrophilic, installing dryers to control moisture values below 1 ppm is essential. In the Isoalky process, HCl and the [Al2Cl7]− anion form super-acidic protons [117,118] that olefinic species accept as base (B) in the alkylation process; this association is described in Equation 11. (11) HCl+B+[Al2Cl7]-→BH++2[AlCl4]- The acidity of protons in ethylmethylimidazolium chloroaluminate was measured at 0.55 mole fraction of AlCl3 to the IL on the Hammet scale. Ma and Jhonson reported a value of −14 [117], while Smith et al. [7] reported a value of −18. Sulfuric acid has a value of −10.6 and HF −10.7. These values indicate that HCl dissolved in the IL is 3 orders of magnitude higher than conventional catalysts in the alkylation process. Because of this higher activity, a much smaller catalyst amount and shorter residence time are required using the Isoalky catalytic process, specifically using a 3–6 vol.% loading compared to the 50% used with sulfuric acid or 60–75% used with HF. Another advantage of the Isoalky catalytic system is its 0–50 °C operating temperature range. Regarding the RON, under identical operating conditions, gasoline obtained with the Isoalky process yields 98, and gasoline by the traditional method yields a value of 96, both obtained with an alkylation reactor temperature of 20 °C. Because of its proprietary technology (Dangling), many of the fundamental design and operational aspects of the novel stages of the Isoalky process are not disclosed. However, some of the operating parameters are disclosed: the reaction medium is of a two-phase nature, which consists of hydrocarbon and dispersed ILs catalyst droplets, which is supplied through various injection nozzles, operating pressure 40–250 psig, isobutane/olefin molar ratio of 8/10, catalyst loading 3–6 vol%, which yielded an olefin conversion > 99. 9%, polymer formation 0.3–0.5 wt.% of input olefins. One of the critical steps in every catalytic process is catalyst recovery. In the case of Isoalky, there is a coalescence process on a high specific area pad of high polarity material that attracts the catalyst and is subsequently removed by gravity. Once the catalyst is removed, the hydrocarbon stream (propane, n-butane, and alkylate) is sent to a distillation column. The formed polymer can deactivate the catalyst. Therefore, its removal is necessary; this is achieved by sending the polymer to a complementary process that converts it into gasoline and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), then the stream is sent to the distillation section. As a result, catalyst reuse is very high due to continuous regeneration. As shown, the Isoalky technology has several advantages over conventional processes for the production of alkylate gasoline. These advantages cover technical, economic, safety, and environmental aspects. Therefore, it is considered that the industrial implementation of this technology will bring new opportunities to oil refiners globally. Therefore, this technology is considered to be the most critical application by volume of ILs to date. Ionikilatyon™ technology The development and fine-tuning of an alternative technology that can efficiently perform the alkylation of paraffinic fractions without using the dangerous and polluting processes based on sulfuric acid and hydrofluoric acid catalysts is one of the most significant contributions to the modern refining industry [120]. Ionikilatyion™ process technology started from research reported in 1994 on the design of catalytic materials based on aluminum chloride and ILs [6]. In 2003, a pilot plant was built to produce 20 tons per year (TPY). Subsequently, at PetroChina's facilities, an alkylation unit with H2SO4 was conditioned to produce 65,000 TPY, which was considered a successful commercial test. By 2013, Deyan Chemical Co, Ltd. built and commissioned a 100,000 TPY plant. Subsequently, in 2018, six more units were licensed, and PetroChina-Harbin put them into operation for 150,000 TPY. The commissioning continued to grow in the following year, and Sinopec Jiujiang achieved 300,000 TPY while PetroChina-Qinghai did so with a 50,000 TPY plant. By 2020, Sinopec Wuhan put a plant for 300,000 TPY while Sinopec Anqing is waiting to operate facilities for the same production capacity; the above with prospecting information as of the last quarter of 2020 [120]. Technical milestones marked the crucial stages in the research and development of this technology. At the beginning of the research, it was possible to obtain no toxic ILs that were efficient in the target reaction, together with a fraction of AlCl3 and another of HCl. Unfortunately, this catalytic composition was corrosive. Subsequently, CH3OCH3, some aromatic components, and CuCl2 were added, producing a complex suspension to separate. The final stage was to obtain composite ILs, which presented adequate handling behavior and catalytic efficiency, which constitutes the core of the new Ionikylation technology. The overall process consists of several sub-processes. The first one is the feed pre-treatment, followed by the reaction, then the separation of products, and finally the regeneration of the catalyst. The flow diagram is presented in Fig. 21 . The feed pretreatment (olefin mixture) removes contaminants such as water, sulfur, and oxygenated compounds. Subsequently, in the alkylation reactor, this input stream is mixed with a homogeneous, continuously circulating dense catalyst phase (composite ionic liquid, CILs) to facilitate the alkylation reaction. Then, the reactor effluent is fed to a series of settlers and separators that differentiate the alkylate mixture and other light components from the high-density catalyst. Next, the alkylate and light components are subjected to fractionation, and unconverted reactants such as isobutane and n-butane are recycled according to particular specifications. Finally, the alkylate stream can be subjected to post-treatments for chloride removal (e.g., absorption). In the bottoms extraction, small amounts of catalyst can be found in solids, while the bulk of the catalyst is sent to the regeneration unit. At the regeneration unit outlet, a makeup stream is introduced, and they are returned to the alkylation reactor, where a chlorine-organic compound is also added to increase the catalytic activity. This process delivers the high-octane components of gasoline, such as TMP. On the other hand, undesirable fractions such as acid oils and azo compounds are decreased. Another advantage is that catalyst regeneration is carried out under relatively moderate conditions, which reduces energy consumption compared to regeneration treatments of traditional acid catalysts. Another achievement of this technology is that carbon steel can be used to construct all equipment since the substances involved in all the process stages are non-corrosive. Table 5 presents a comparative analysis of key features of the traditional H2SO4, HF, with the new tendencies of Isoalky and Ionikylation (CILs) technologies. It is observed that it presents desirable characteristics for implementation both from the safety point of view, as it involves non-corrosive compounds and technical advantages involving high catalytic activity and selectivity towards obtaining alkylated compounds. The new technologies have operational advantages over the conventional ones. For example, they can work within a broader temperature range; however, although it has been proven that using this technology, the obtained alkylate has a higher RON, the costs can be higher because it is necessary to install additional equipment to cool the feed. Moreover, catalyst regeneration stages similar to the conventional ones are required, offset by the lower amount of catalyst required since it is necessary to remove acidified oils. Additional advantages include increased process safety by not using hazardous materials and eliminating emissions and caustic waste effluents. An essential point in the operation of the Ionikylation process is the feedstock pretreatment. Therefore, it is essential to take care of some aspects to extend the catalyst lifetime and increase its efficiency to obtain alkylated components with a RON of 95–96. Table 6 describes some feed limitations and the recommended control aspects. After analyzing the various characteristics of the Ionikylation technology, it can be summarized that it is a competitive process to the traditional alkylation processes since it equals and in other cases surpasses their performance. The highlighted beneficial aspects are excellent safety in its operation, adaptability to existing units, and successful commercial tests. Conclusions As seen throughout this review, ILs represent a promising alternative as novel catalysts for the isobutane/butene alkylation reaction; these compounds belong to a new generation of catalysts called to replace current technologies based on highly toxic and corrosive acid H2SO4 and HF. Due to physicochemical properties such as extremely low vapor pressure, low corrosivity, and tunable Lewis and/or Brønsted acidic properties, based on results obtained on an industrial scale with some commercial prototypes, ILs seem to be the perfect catalysts of the reaction conceived to produce alkylation gasoline. At present, research continues because the current prototypes used at the industrial level show some stability and selectivity problems; then, improving these properties to achieve highly efficient and stable catalysts is still a significant challenge. Research in ILs for alkylation reactions has been very prolific in the last decades, such as looking for improved Lewis and/or Brønsted acidic properties to develop composites, ILs combined with different additives, organic and inorganic acids, and supported ILs have also been explored. Brønsted acids generally lack sufficient acidity to achieve adequate conversion and selectivity to TMP, but their activity can be significantly increased when combined with certain additives. ILs derived from organometallic compounds represent a promising alternative to conventional acids due to their adaptation suitability to both Lewis and Brønsted acidity; however, their sensitivity to moisture seems to be a significant challenge to be solved despite strategies for their in-situ regeneration. ILs containing both Brønsted and Lewis sites in their structure show excellent selectivity and performance, and the chemical stability in the presence of moisture is greatly improved in ILs containing only Lewis acid sites. Supported ILs have the distinct advantages of heterogeneous catalytic systems and can be designed with Brønsted and Lewis sites from the ILs and support. Porous supports generate zones that favor the interaction between the ILs and substrate active sites, requiring smaller ILs/feed ratio, minimizing cross-contamination and product losses during the separation of product and catalyst; then, these materials also constitute a desirable alternative to polyILs, which have similar advantages and represent an unexplored area within this topic. Despite the efforts made so far, ILs as catalysts for the isobutane/butene alkylation reaction has many fundamental aspects not yet fully understood, such as mass transfer models, viscosity effects, and Lewis and Brønsted acidity balance correlation with the catalytic activity. In addition, many aspects regarding the synthesis, atomic economy, and large-scale regeneration of ILs still need to be refined to develop a truly efficient and sustainable process that is expected to be reached in the near future. coredata.dc:description: The isobutane/butene alkylation reaction is one of the most crucial refining processes since it gives rise to high octane and high purity gasoline, one of the main contributors to the gasoline pool. Conventionally, the alkylation reaction is carried out industrially using hydrofluoric and sulfuric acids, which have significant safety, corrosivity, recyclability, and sustainability concerns, making the development of efficient, environmentally friendly, and sustainable catalysts for this reaction an active research topic. Due to their attractive physicochemical properties, ionic liquids seem to be the most promising alternative to replace the catalysts commonly used at the industrial level. The present compendium reviews research works to develop ionic liquids as catalysts of the isobutane/butane reaction to obtain a more efficient, sustainable, and environmentally friendly process. These compounds can mitigate the environmental problems associated with inorganic acids that have been used for many years as catalysts of this reaction on an industrial scale. The most recent articles and patents dealing with the advances in the alkylation reaction employing commercial technologies to obtain alkylated gasoline based on ionic-liquid catalysts, which have not been featured in previous reviews, are emphasized and discussed here.
coredata.dc:title: Isobutane/butene alkylation reaction using ionic liquids as catalysts. Toward a sustainable industry
